choices.text: Non-significant expectoration is common in cases of Upper respiratory tract infection
Sputum production more than 100ml/day is bronchorrhea
Significant expectoration is common in Pleural effusion

questions.text: Respiratory system disorders commonly present with cough. Following statements are true regarding the symptom EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Significant expectoration is common in Pleural effusion

Cough can be classified into “Significant” and “non-significant” expectoration.

Non-significant expectoration is common feature in Upper respiratory tract infection. It is also seen in Interstitial and Pleural disorders (Do not communicate with airways)

Normal sputum production is 60-100ml/day. Quantity >100ml/day is bronchorrhea.

The presence of bronchorrhea, mucopurulent/foul-smelling sputum with hemoptysis is significant expectoration. It is common in Airway/parenchymal disorders.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady presents with recurrent episodes of mucopurulent sputum. She has history of TB during adolescence. On examination, severe clubbing is present with coarse crepitations with post-tussive changes on auscultation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bronchiectasis

Post-tussive changes on auscultation are characteristic of Post-TB bronchiectasis. On coughing, there will be clearance of the pooled mucus secretions leading to change in the auscultation findings.

choices.text: Most commonly affects Left Lower bronchus

questions.text: Following statements are True regarding Bronchiectasis EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Can be confirmed on Spirometry

Bronchiectasis is a post-infective sequalae (MC is Post-TB in the world) affecting middle aged females. The Left Lower bronchus is affected due to its anatomy causing poor drainage of secretions. Being a structural disease, the GS of diagnosis is HRCT.

Spirometry is diagnostic in cases of Obstructive airway disorders.

questions.text: A 63-year-old gentleman, chronic smoker had a 3 year history of cough with intermittent episodes of fever and breathlessness. CXR revealed prominent Broncho-vesicular markings with Cardiomegaly. Recently he reports weight loss of 6kg in last 2 months. On examination, there is Grade 3 clubbing. What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bronchogenic Carcinoma. COLD does not cause clubbing. 

In a patient with COLD, the presence of clubbing indicates super-added infection / Bronchogenic carcinoma.

choices.text: CT scan of the chest without contrast

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with known very severe COPD who continues to smoke cigarettes presents to his doctor with increasing weight gain and bilateral lower leg edema over several weeks. On examination, he has an elevated jugular venous pulsation and bilateral lower leg edema that extend to his knees. An electrocardiogram shows right ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Echocardiography

This patient with very severe COPD is now presenting with signs of cor pulmonale, including increased jugular venous distention, weight gain, and bilateral leg edema and characteristic changes on electrocardiography. The most appropriate test to confirm this diagnosis would be echocardiography. 
Since he is known to have COPD, spirometry would not provide further useful information. Duplex ultrasonography and contrast-enhanced CT are not indicated, as the suspicion for venous thrombo-embolism is low. Bronchoscopy would not be helpful in the evaluation of cor pulmonale.

questions.text: All the lung volumes are measured on Spirometry EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Residual Volume

Spirometry can measure dynamic lung volumes, mainly FVC and FEV1. However, Residual volume(RV), Functional Reserve Capacity(FRC) and Total Lung capacity(TLC) needs Plethysmography for measurement.

questions.text: Tiffeneau-Pinelli Index < 0.70 is diagnostic of which lung disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Obstructive lung disease

Tiffeneau-Pinelli index is the ratio of FEV1/FVC on Spirometry.

In Obstructive lung disease, the expiratory volume (FEV1) is predominantly affected leading to lowering of the ratio. Normal value of the ratio is 0.75. Value lower than 0.70 is specific for Obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: Increased FEV1/FVC ratio with Reduced DLCO suggests following pathology
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Silicosis

Increased FEV1/FVC ratio (Tiffeneau-Pinelli ratio) suggested Restrictive lung disease.

Restrictive lung diseases based on DLCO (Diffusion capacity of lung to carbon monoxide) are divide into parenchymal and extra-parenchymal causes. If the DLCO is reduced, it indicates a parenchymal cause (e.g. ILD). Presence of Normal DLCO would suggest Extra- parenchymal causes (e.g. kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylosis)

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presents for evaluation of SOB without wheezing or cough. She is being treated for SLE and her PFT results are given below. Most probable abnormality is: FEV1 - 85% of Predicted FVC - 65% of Predicted FEV1/FVC ratio – Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Restrictive pattern of ILD

Ratio is not reduced so obstructive can be ruled out. In above ratio is maintained and FVC is reduced suggestive of restrictive defect which can be due to underlying ILD in a case of SLE

questions.text: Decreased DLCO is found in all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Congestive Heart failure

In CHF, there is congestion of the pulmonary capillaries which facilitates diffusion and INCREASES DLCO.

questions.text: In a patient with hypoxemia, which of the following arterial blood gas (ABG) findings would you expect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

PaO2 60 mmHg, SaO2 88%

Explanation: In hypoxemia, the PaO2 is typically lower than normal (less than 80 mmHg), and the oxygen saturation (SaO2) is also reduced (less than 90%).

questions.text: In a patient with metabolic acidosis, which of the following arterial blood gas (ABG) findings would you expect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

pH 7.30, HCO3- 18 mEq/L

Explanation: In metabolic acidosis, the pH is typically low (less than 7.35), and the bicarbonate (HCO3-) level is also low (less than 22 mEq/L). The values in option B reflect these changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diabetic ketoacidosis

Explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis is a common cause of metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of ketone bodies, which are acidic. Hyperventilation and hypoventilation are related to respiratory acidosis/alkalosis, and excessive vomiting typically leads to metabolic alkalosis due to loss of stomach acid.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT typically associated with metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyperaldosteronism

Explanation: Hyperaldosteronism is typically associated with metabolic alkalosis due to increased reabsorption of sodium and bicarbonate. Renal failure, severe diarrhea, and aspirin overdose are common causes of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A patient has the following ABG results: pH 7.30, PaCO2 50 mmHg, HCO3- 24 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Respiratory acidosis

Explanation: The low pH (7.30) indicates acidosis. The elevated PaCO2 (50 mmHg) suggests that the acidosis is due to respiratory causes, as CO2 retention is causing the pH to drop.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a high pH and low PaCO2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low PaCO2, indicating excessive elimination of CO2 due to hyperventilation.

questions.text: Which is the most common ABB defect during Pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation: During pregnancy, the high progesterone level sensitizes the respiratory Centre to hypoxemia. Gravid uterus may restrict movement of diaphragm. Both mechanisms promote hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: The best treatment for Mild case of acute of Asthma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Formeterol + ICS nebulization

As per GINA guidelines, the best treatment for Acute attack of Mild asthma is LABA + ICS nebulization. This relieves symptoms as well as prevents relapse pf symptoms.

SABA (Salbutamol) alone only relieves the symptoms but short-acting.

Salmeterol is ONLY for prophylaxis. 

Mechanical ventilation is for severe attack of acute asthma

questions.text: The Mechanism of action for Tezepelumab is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

TSLP inhibitor

Tezepelumab is the first in class TSLP inhibitor approved for Asthma prophylaxis. TSLP is Thymic Stromal Lymphopoietin which is an important mediator of airway inflammation.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for diagnosis of ILD is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HRCT

HRCT showing GGO – Ground glass opacities is diagnostic of ILD

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common symptom of Interstitial Lung Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hemoptysis

Explanation: Hemoptysis (coughing up blood) is less common in ILD compared to symptoms like shortness of breath, chronic dry cough, and chest pain. ILD primarily affects the lung interstitium, leading to fibrosis and inflammation, which typically present with respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following interstitial lung diseases is associated with granuloma formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sarcoidosis

Explanation: Sarcoidosis is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are small clusters of inflammatory cells. This differentiates it from other ILDs like IPF, asbestosis, and hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which do not typically involve granuloma formation.

questions.text: What is the hallmark radiographic feature of UIP (Usual Interstitial Pneumonia)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Honeycombing

Explanation: Honeycombing is a hallmark feature of UIP seen on high-resolution CT scans. It appears as clustered cystic air spaces, usually at the lung periphery, and indicates advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: Match the Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis syndromes with the corresponding antigen :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-(2), B-(4), C-(1), D-(3)

questions.text: Match the broncho-alveolar findings with the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1-(B), 2-(A), 3-(D), 4-(C)

questions.text: The most common mechanism of hypoxemia in practise is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

V:Q mismatch disorders

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with features of acute pancreatitis. Few days later he developed dyspnoea. His ABG reveals Ph : 7.46 PaCO2 : 25 HCO3 – 22 PaO2 : 55 mm Hg His chest X ray is shown below. What is the type of respiratory failure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type 1 

H/o pancreatitis + acute SOB + hypoxemia on ABG + B/L diffuse pulmonary infiltrates is suggestive of ARDS. In ARDS common is Type 1 respiratory failure

questions.text: Carrico’s index in ARDS is calculated as :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carrico’s index is PaO2/FiO2. This is the most important parameter for both diagnosis and prognosis of ARDS.

questions.text: A 67-year old woman is admitted to the casualty with pyrexia (38.1) and a cough productive of green sputum. The observations show a Pulse rate of 101/min, BP 80/60 and Respiratory rate of 32/min. She is alert and oriented in time and space. Investigations reveal TLC of 21000, Urea of 8.5 and x-ray reveals consolidation in the right lung. She is treated for CAP. Which of the following is the correct calculated CURB 65 score ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Total score is 4.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with unexplained weight loss, loss of appetite and shortness of breath comes to your clinic. On examination, there is reduced air entry and dullness on percussion in the right lung. A diagnostic pleural tap was performed and aspirate sent for analysis. The result reveals a Serum to Pleural fluid albumin gradient of 1.1. From the given list, select the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bronchogenic carcinoma

Serum to Pleural fluid albumin gradient <1.2 is specific for diagnosis of exudative effusion. 

Along with the clinical history of weight loss, it supports a diagnosis of malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common causative agent of Community Acquired Pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Explanation: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial cause of CAP, responsible for a significant proportion of cases.

questions.text: What is the recommended first-line antibiotic treatment for a previously healthy outpatient with Community Acquired Pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Azithromycin

Explanation: Azithromycin is often recommended as a first-line treatment for outpatients with CAP who have no comorbidities or recent antibiotic use.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of transudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Explanation: Transudative pleural effusions are typically caused by systemic factors that alter the balance of hydrostatic and oncotic pressures, with CHF being the most common cause.

questions.text: Which diagnostic criteria are used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Light’s Criteria

Explanation: Light’s Criteria are used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions based on the levels of protein and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid compared to serum levels.

questions.text: What is the most definitive diagnostic procedure for identifying the cause of a pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thoracentesis

Explanation: Thoracentesis involves the removal of pleural fluid for analysis and is the most definitive diagnostic procedure for identifying the cause of a pleural effusion

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH

questions.text: Which of the following findings in pleural fluid analysis suggests an exudative effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH

Explanation: According to Light’s Criteria, an exudative effusion is indicated if the pleural fluid LDH is greater than 2/3 of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH, among other criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom of Pulmonary Embolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sudden onset of dyspnea

Explanation: The sudden onset of dyspnea (shortness of breath) is the most common symptom of PE, often accompanied by chest pain and tachypnea (rapid breathing).

questions.text: Which imaging test is considered the gold standard for diagnosing Pulmonary Embolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT pulmonary angiography

Explanation: CT pulmonary angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing PE as it provides detailed images of the pulmonary arteries and can detect blockages.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is commonly used to help rule out Pulmonary Embolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

D-dimer test

Explanation: The D-dimer test measures the presence of fibrin degradation products in the blood, which are elevated in the presence of a blood clot. A negative D-dimer test can help rule out PE in patients with a low clinical probability.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary treatment option for Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Endothelin receptor antagonists

Explanation: Endothelin receptor antagonists, such as bosentan and ambrisentan, are commonly used to treat PAH by blocking the effects of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor. This helps to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve symptoms.

questions.text: The most common cause of Anaemia in CKD cases is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

A. EPO deficiency

Explanation: In chronic kidney disease (CKD), the kidneys are unable to produce adequate amounts of erythropoietin (EPO), a hormone responsible for stimulating the production of red blood cells in the bone marrow. This deficiency in EPO leads to anemia, which is very common in CKD patients.

Incorrect options:

B. Malaena

Explanation: Malaena refers to the passage of black, tarry stools, often due to gastrointestinal bleeding. While GI bleeding can contribute to anemia, it is not the most common cause of anemia in CKD patients. EPO deficiency is a more direct and prevalent cause of anemia in CKD.

C. Occult sepsis

Explanation: Occult sepsis can lead to anemia, but it typically causes anemia through chronic inflammation, which can suppress bone marrow function. However, EPO deficiency is still the more direct and common cause of anemia in CKD.

D. Coagulopathy

Explanation: Coagulopathy refers to a disorder where the blood doesn't clot properly. While CKD can increase the risk of bleeding due to platelet dysfunction, coagulopathy does not directly cause anemia. It might contribute to blood loss, but EPO deficiency remains the primary cause of anemia in CKD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dehydration

Explanation: Pre-renal AKI is caused by factors that reduce blood flow to the kidneys, such as dehydration, which leads to decreased perfusion and subsequent kidney injury.

questions.text: Which laboratory finding is typically elevated in acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Serum creatinine

Explanation: Serum creatinine is a key marker for kidney function. In AKI, serum creatinine levels rise due to impaired kidney function and decreased clearance of creatinine from the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is a potential complication of acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hyperkalemia

Explanation: Hyperkalemia (elevated potassium levels) is a common and serious complication of AKI due to the kidneys’ reduced ability to excrete potassium, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: What is definition of Oliguria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

<400ml/day

Explanation: The oliguric stage of AKI is marked by a significant decrease in urine output (less than 400 mL/day), indicating severe kidney dysfunction and the need for close monitoring and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for emergency Hemodialysis in a case of AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Encephalopathy

Emergency dialysis is indicated in several critical situations where immediate intervention is necessary to prevent severe complications. The main indications for emergency dialysis can be remembered using the mnemonic “AEIOU”:

1.	Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.2) that is refractory to bicarbonate therapy.

2.	Electrolytes: Life-threatening hyperkalemia (potassium > 6.5 mmol/L) or lower with ECG changes, and other severe electrolyte imbalances.

3.	Ingestions: Toxic ingestions, such as lithium or ethylene glycol poisoning.

4.	Overload: Fluid overload, particularly pulmonary edema, that is unresponsive to diuretics.

5.	Uremia: Symptomatic uremia, which may present with encephalopathy, pericarditis, neuropathy, seizures, severe bleeding due to platelet dysfunction, or intractable nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used to diagnose Acute Kidney Injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

KDIGO criteria

Explanation: The KDIGO criteria (Kidney diseases: Improving Global outcome) is used to diagnose AKI. It includes Urine output and Rise in Serum Creatinine.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive parameter to differentiate Pre-renal AKI form Intrinsic AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

FeNa

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of nephritic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hematuria

Explanation: Nephritic syndrome is characterized by hematuria (blood in the urine), hypertension, and mild to moderate proteinuria. This is in contrast to nephrotic syndrome, which features massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of post-infectious glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Streptococcus

Explanation: Post-infectious glomerulonephritis is most commonly caused by Streptococcus, particularly following a streptococcal throat or skin infection. This condition is known as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

questions.text: Which type of glomerulonephritis is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Goodpasture’s syndrome

Explanation: Goodpasture’s syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, which attack the basement membrane in both the kidneys and lungs, leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is incidentally detected to have hematuria. Her symptoms started 10 days after developing a sore throat and. Her blood pressure was 150/80 mm Hg. Urinalysis was positive for blood(4+) and Protein (2+) .Which of the following is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-DNAase is the most sensitive antibody present in PSGN

questions.text: 25yrs. Male presented with haematuria 3 days following sore throat and fever. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBC. However, the renal function test for normal. Serum C3 levels were normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Berger’s disease (IgA nephropathy) also called syn-pharyngitic nephropathy is post infective GN occurring within the first week of URTI. Majority patients have preserved renal function with normal C3 levels.

questions.text: The most common extra-renal manifestation in APKD is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic dysfunction due to mechanical compression of IHBR causes cholestatic jaundice.

questions.text: 44yrs. Diabetic male presents with bilateral pedal edema with gross proteinuria. He is diagnosed with diabetes for last 8 years and poorly compliant with his medications. 6 months ago, he was also detected to have retinopathy. On examination, the BP was 160/110mm of Hg. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

FSGS.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with Alport Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

COL4A5

Explanation: Alport Syndrome is most commonly associated with mutations in the COL4A5 gene, which encodes the alpha-5 chain of type IV collagen. This mutation leads to defects in the glomerular basement membrane, resulting in kidney disease, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.

questions.text: What is a characteristic ocular finding in patients with Alport Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anterior lenticonus

Explanation: Anterior lenticonus, a condition where the lens of the eye becomes cone-shaped, is a characteristic ocular finding in Alport Syndrome. This occurs due to the weakening of the lens capsule caused by defective type IV collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Alport Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above

Explanation: Alport Syndrome commonly presents with hematuria (blood in the urine), proteinuria (protein in the urine), and sensorineural hearing loss. These symptoms result from the defective type IV collagen affecting the kidneys, ears, and eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary goal in the management of Chronic Kidney Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Control blood pressure

Explanation: Controlling blood pressure is a primary goal in managing CKD. Hypertension can accelerate the progression of kidney damage, so maintaining optimal blood pressure levels is crucial to slow the disease’s progression.

questions.text: Which medication class is commonly used to reduce proteinuria in patients with CKD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ACE inhibitors

Explanation: ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril, lisinopril) are commonly used to reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of CKD. They work by dilating blood vessels and reducing the pressure in the glomeruli, thereby decreasing protein leakage into the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest clinical manifestation of Diabetic Nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Microalbuminuria

Explanation: Microalbuminuria, defined as a small amount of albumin in the urine, is the earliest clinical sign of Diabetic Nephropathy. It indicates early kidney damage before significant proteinuria develops.

questions.text: What is the recommended screening test for early detection of Diabetic Nephropathy in patients with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR)

Explanation: The spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) is the recommended screening test for early detection of Diabetic Nephropathy. It is a convenient and accurate method to detect microalbuminuria, indicating early kidney damage.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is most commonly associated with SLE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anti-dsDNA

Explanation: Anti-dsDNA (anti-double-stranded DNA) antibodies are highly specific for SLE and are commonly used in the diagnosis and monitoring of the disease. Their presence is strongly associated with lupus nephritis and disease activity.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common clinical manifestation of SLE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bone erosions

Explanation: Bone erosions do not occur in SLE. The joint involvement in SLE is known as Jaccouds arthropathy i.e. Non erosive arthritis. Common symptoms of SLE include arthritis, malar rash (butterfly-shaped rash on the face), and hematuria (blood in the urine) due to lupus nephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hallmark feature of Systemic Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Skin thickening

Explanation: Skin thickening is a hallmark feature of Systemic Sclerosis, also known as scleroderma. It results from excessive collagen deposition in the skin, leading to a tight, shiny appearance.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is most commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody

Explanation: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies are commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis. Their presence is linked to more severe disease and a higher risk of pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hallmark feature of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Synovial inflammation

Explanation: The hallmark feature of RA is synovial inflammation, which leads to joint pain, swelling, and stiffness. This inflammation can eventually cause cartilage and bone damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common extra-articular manifestation of Ankylosing Spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Uveitis

Explanation: Uveitis, an inflammation of the uvea in the eye, is a common extra-articular manifestation of Ankylosing Spondylitis. It can cause eye pain, redness, and blurred vision.

questions.text: Which genetic marker is strongly associated with Ankylosing Spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HLA-B27

Explanation: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker strongly associated with Ankylosing Spondylitis. The presence of this marker increases the risk of developing the disease.

questions.text: Which medication is commonly used as a first-line treatment for Rheumatoid Arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Methotrexate

Explanation: Methotrexate is commonly used as a first-line treatment for RA. It is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that helps reduce inflammation and slow disease progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic skin manifestation of Dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gottron’s papules

Explanation: Gottron’s papules are a characteristic skin manifestation of Dermatomyositis. They appear as raised, violaceous lesions over the knuckles, elbows, and knees, and are often associated with muscle weakness.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is commonly associated with Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anti-Jo-1

Explanation: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are commonly associated with Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis. Their presence is linked to an increased risk of interstitial lung disease and other systemic manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asymmetric distal muscle weakness

Explanation: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) typically presents with asymmetric distal muscle weakness, particularly affecting the quadriceps and finger flexors. This distinguishes it from other inflammatory myopathies, which usually present with symmetric proximal muscle weakness

questions.text: Which vasculitis syndrome is most commonly associated with asthma and eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)

Explanation: Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous inflammation. It primarily affects small to medium-sized vessels.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is commonly associated with Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-MPO (Myeloperoxidase)

Explanation: Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) is commonly associated with anti-MPO (myeloperoxidase) antibodies. These antibodies are part of the ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) group and are used in the diagnosis of MPA.
